Fast and Robust Certifiable Estimation of the Relative Pose Between Two Calibrated Cameras

Mercedes Garcia-Salguero1 and Javier Gonzalez-Jimenez2
Machine Perception and Intelligent Robotics (MAPIR) Group, System Engineering and Automation Department,
University of Malaga, Campus de Teatinos, 29071 Malaga, Spain
Email: 1mercedesgarsal@uma.es, 2javiergonzalez@uma.es
Abstract

This work contributes an efficient algorithm to compute the Relative Pose problem (RPp) between calibrated cameras and certify the optimality of the solution, given a set of pair-wise feature correspondences affected by noise and probably corrupted by wrong matches. We propose a family of certifiers that is shown to increase the ratio of detected optimal solutions. This set of certifiers is incorporated into a fast essential matrix estimation pipeline that, given any initial guess for the RPp, refines it iteratively on the product space of 3D rotations and 2-sphere. In addition, this fast certifiable pipeline is integrated into a robust framework that combines Graduated Non-convexity and the Black-Rangarajan duality between robust functions and line processes.

We proved through extensive experiments on synthetic and real data that the proposed framework provides a fast and robust relative pose estimation. We make the code publicly available https://github.com/mergarsal/FastCertRelPose.git.

I Introduction

The Relative Pose problem (RPp) consists of finding the relative rotation ğ‘¹ğ‘¹\bm{R} and translation ğ’•ğ’•\bm{t} between two central, calibrated cameras given a set of Nğ‘N pair-wise feature correspondences (ğ’‡i,ğ’‡iâ€²)subscriptğ’‡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–â€²(\bm{f}_{i},\bm{f}_{i}^{\prime}), as shown in FigureÂ (1). Since the scale cannot be recovered for this type of configurations, the translation component is estimated only up-to-scaleÂ [1].

Estimating the relative pose from visual data is the cornerstone of tasks such as visual odometry Â [2, 3, 4], and more complex computer vision problems e.g., Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) Â [5, 6, 7] and Structure-from-Motion (SfM) Â [8, 9, 10]. The gold-standard approach for RPpÂ  poses it as a 2-view Bundle Adjustment (BA) that minimizes the reprojection error Â [1, 11, 12]. This is a non-convex problem that typically presents multiple local minima. Since the algorithms employed for its resolution are iterative, they are prone to get stuck in suboptimal solutions, which may lay arbitrarily far away from the global minimum. The lack of quality of these solutions may hinder the subsequent blocks of the applications that leverage them, leading to inaccurate solutions or even to the complete failure of the application. An example of the last case is shown in FigureÂ (2), where the left reconstruction employs all the solutions, while the right reconstruction only employed those solutions certified as global optima (we return to this certification later on this introduction). Therefore, special attention must be given to this fundamental and early block on these complex applications.

In order to try to avoid these suboptimal solutions for the RPp, a good initialization is usually required Â [14]. If this initial guess is within the attraction basin of the optimal solution, the iterative method will return it with high probability Â [11]. Although, in general, the quality of the initial guess cannot be measured, it has been reported in the literature that simplifications of the problem lead to good initializations. A common simplification for the RPpÂ  relies on the algebraic error and the so-called essential matrix ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E}Â [1], which is a 3Ã—3333\times 3 matrix that encapsulates all the geometric information about the relative pose (rotation and translation) and it is defined as ğ‘¬â‰[ğ’•]Ã—â€‹ğ‘¹approaches-limitğ‘¬subscriptdelimited-[]ğ’•ğ‘¹\bm{E}\doteq[\bm{t}]_{\times}\bm{R}, where [ğ’•]Ã—subscriptdelimited-[]ğ’•[\bm{t}]_{\times} denotes the matrix form for the cross-product for a 333D vector such that ğ’•Ã—âˆ™=[ğ’•]Ã—âˆ™\bm{t}\times\bullet=[\bm{t}]_{\times}\bullet (we define its explicit form later in Equation (1)).

The essential matrix constrains the pair-wise correspondences (ğ’‡i,ğ’‡iâ€²)subscriptğ’‡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–â€²(\bm{f}_{i},\bm{f}_{i}^{\prime}) via the epipolar constraint, formally defined as ğ’‡iTâ€‹ğ‘¬â€‹ğ’‡iâ€²=0superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğ‘¬superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–â€²0\bm{f}_{i}^{T}\bm{E}\bm{f}_{i}^{\prime}=0. Here the observations ğ’‡i,ğ’‡iâ€²subscriptğ’‡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–â€²\bm{f}_{i},\bm{f}_{i}^{\prime} are 3D vectors, which can be expressed in homogeneous coordinates (last entry to one) or normalized (Euclidean norm to one). While this relation holds for all the correspondences when they are noiseless, in real scenarios ğ’‡iTâ€‹ğ‘¬â€‹ğ’‡iâ€²=Ïµisuperscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğ‘¬superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–â€²subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\bm{f}_{i}^{T}\bm{E}\bm{f}_{i}^{\prime}=\epsilon_{i}, with Ïµiâ‰ 0subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–0\epsilon_{i}\neq 0, usually known as the epipolar error. A common approach leverages this relation in order to find the â€œbestâ€œ essential matrix in terms of this error, i.e. we seek the ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E} that minimizes Ïµi2superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2\epsilon_{i}^{2} for all the correspondences, âˆ‘i=1NÏµi2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2\sum_{i=1}^{N}\epsilon_{i}^{2}Â [1, 15]. Although more complex errors are employed in the literature, see for exampleÂ [16, 17], this is already a complex, non-convex problem, hence presenting multiple local minima.

The relative pose, and hence the essential matrix, has five degrees of freedom, three for the 3D rotation, three for the 3D translation and one less due to the scale ambiguity. Since the epipolar constraint is linear in the entries of ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E}, at least five correspondences are required to estimate it (except for degenerate casesÂ [1, 18]). This is known as the minimal solver (the five-point algorithm, 5-pt ) Â [19, 20]. This solver can be embedded into robust paradigms, such as RANSAC Â [21, 22], in order to gain robustness against wrong correspondences, i.e. outliers.

Although the 5-pt is the minimal solver for this problem, another common approach is the eight-point algorithm, 8-pt Â [23, 1, 24]. This method employs eight points, and although it was initially devised for the fundamental matrix, the equivalent version of the essential matrix for uncalibrated cameras, it can be adapted to the calibrated case in a straightforward manner. The main advantage of this solver is its simplicity, since the solution is obtained by first computing the Singular Value Decomposition of the data matrix (formed by the pair-wise correspondences) and then projecting the right singular vector associated with the smallest singular value onto the space of essential matricesÂ [1, 24]. Further, this approach admits an extension that includes all the correspondences, known as the Direct Linear Transformation (DLT). However, the solution found by these methods is only the global optimum in theory when correspondences are noiseless Â [25]. These (suboptimal) solutions from the closed-form solvers are usually refined by iterative algorithms that respect the intrinsic constraints of the essential matrices, seeÂ e.g.Â [26, 13, 16]. However, since the problem is still non-convex, these iterative algorithms may still return suboptimal solutions Â [14].

Some works have proposed certifiable solvers for the non-minimal RPp, that is, solvers that guarantee that the returned solution is the global optimum, among othersÂ [27, 15, 12]. They make use of off-the-shelf optimization tools that have polynomial or even exponential time complexity. Although fast implementations has been reported, seeÂ [15], they are still slow for the computer vision standards (303030 fps). On the bright side, these solvers are not the only ones that are able to certify optimality. BanderiaÂ [28] characterized the so-called Certifiable Algorithms that, for a given solution to a non-convex problem (obtained by any means) and for most real-world problem instances, are able to certify if the solution is optimal, provided some conditions are fulfilled. Such certifiable algorithms have been reported previously in the literature for other problems, such as rotation averagingÂ [29], point set registration Â [30, 31] or pose graph optimization Â [32, 33, 34]. The main advantage of these approaches is that they are usually faster in terms of certification than the above-mentioned certifiable proposals. Further, since the solution to the non-convex problem can be estimated by any iterative method, the estimation stage is also faster than the exponential tools, see e.g.Â [26]. InÂ [13], we proposed for the first time this kind of certifiable algorithm for the RPp, which was demonstrated to be faster than the state-of-the-art solver under a matlabÂ implementation.

Nevertheless, the above-mentioned approaches (with some exceptions, likeÂ [15]) do not consider explicitly the presence of bad correspondences (outliers), which strongly affect the accuracy of the solution. Outliers are common in real-world problem instances due to the nature of the feature detection algorithms and matching processes. The classic approach to detect these bad correspondences relies on the embedding of a minimal solver into a RANSAC framework Â [22, 11, 35]. The returned set of inliers is then employed to estimate the essential matrix by any of the previously mentioned methods. To overcome some of the limitations that such strategies present, attention has been recently directed to tools known as Graduated Non-convexity (GNC) Â [36] and the Black-Rangarajan (BR)Â [37] duality between robust estimations and line processes. In combination, they permit to estimate both the set of inliers and the solution to a given (non-convex) problem. The potential of these tools has been reported in, for example, Â [15, 38, 39], demonstrating to outperform RANSAC-based strategies in accuracy while being robust up to a higher percentage of outliers.

Contributions: In this work, we extend our proposal inÂ [13] for the RPp with two significant improvements: a family of optimality certifiers and a robust paradigm for the non-minimal solver based on GNC and BR.

More precisely, the main technical contributions of the present work are:

  1. 1.

    We define in SectionÂ (V) the set of optimality certifiers associated with the different relaxations of the set of essential matrices. This family of certifiers is shown to detect (certify) more optimal solutions, overcoming in most problem instances the limitations associated with the different relaxations and their tightness.

  2. 2.

    We provide in SectionÂ (V-A) the quadratic Euclidean model of the RPpÂ whose objective function is the squared, normalized epipolar error, defined over the product space of 3D rotation matrices and the 2-sphere. A preconditioner that decreases the convergence time of the iterative method is also provided.

  3. 3.

    We illustrate in SectionÂ (VI) the embedding of the RPpÂ into the robust framework formed by the combination of GNC and BR, providing also a general library for its utilization (not restricted to the RPp) in https://github.com/mergarsal/GNCSO.git.

  4. 4.

    We perform extensive experiments in SectionÂ (VII) on both synthetic and real data and compare our proposal against the state-of-the-art solvers under a wide variety of configurations. We also report the influence of our method in the performance of 2-view BA against the common initializations.

As an additional contribution, we release the code for this version of our work in
https://github.com/mergarsal/FastCertRelPose.git.

Notice that, although we show in SectionÂ (VII) that strong duality usually holds for the RPpÂ  and the chosen relaxations (from which our certifiers are derived), a formal proof of this behavior is not available yet.

Last, we want to point out that while our proposal estimates the essential matrix, the relative rotation and translation up-to-scale can be extracted from it by any classic computer vision algorithmÂ [1].

II Related Work

Here we summarized briefly the solvers proposed in the literature for the Relative Pose problem. For a more detailed list, we refer the reader toÂ [13].

II-A Non-certifiable approaches

Closed-form solvers

The essential matrix has five degrees of freedom (three from 3D rotation, three from 3D translation and one less because the scale ambiguity) and therefore, only five correspondences (except for degenerate casesÂ [1]) are required for its estimation. This is the so-called minimal problem and since it provides us with an efficient hypothesis generator, it can be embedded into a RANSAC framework to gain robustness against wrong correspondences, i.e. outliersÂ [11, 22]. However, this minimal problem involves the resolution of a nontrivial (tenth degree) polynomialÂ [20, 19], and the tools to solve it (e.g. polynomial ideal theory or GrÃ¶bner basis) are not always numerically stable. Hence, some previous works have proposed alternative approaches, see e.g.Â [40, 41].

In post of simplicity, the 888-point algorithm by Faugeras et al.Â [23], which was originally proposed for the fundamental matrix, is usually adapted to the case of the essential matrix, i.e. calibrated cameras. Of significant importance is the extension of the 888-point algorithm that includes all the correspondences, usually known as the Direct Linear Transform (DLT) Â [1].

Iterative solvers

The above-mentioned solvers typically provide suboptimal solutions for the non-minimal N-point problem and therefore it is a common practice to refine these initial estimates by local, iterative methodsÂ [22]. Contrary to optimization problems on flat (Euclidean) spaces, these local optimization methods must respect the intrinsic constraints of the search space, i.e. the solution must be always an essential matrix. Different parameterizations for the set of essential matrices have been proposed, seeÂ e.g.Â [21, 16, 17, 26]. As it was shown in [17], these parameterizations may lead to different performances and convergence rates for non-linear optimization methods. The main difficulty relies on the peculiarities of the epipolar constraints and the symmetry between the two views, which are often not taking into account. The characterization proposed inÂ [26] leverages the concept of quotient manifoldÂ [42] in order to model all these peculiarities. Nevertheless, simple characterizations (e.g., the product space of 3D rotations and 2-sphere) may still work in most problem instances under some conditions, for example, a good initial guess.

II-B Certifiable approaches

Branch-and-Bound

Despite its attractiveness as fast solvers, the above-mentioned methods do not guarantee nor certify if the retrieved solution is optimal. In fact, finding said optimal solutions with guarantees for non-convex problems, such as the Relative Pose problem, is in general a hard task. Nonetheless, approaches with exponential time complexity in worst-case scenarios that rely on Branch-and-Bound global optimization have been proposed for that. In [43], the authors incorporated the presence of outliers as an inlier-set maximization problem. In [12], it was first proposed the estimation of the essential matrix under a Lâˆsubscriptğ¿L_{\infty} cost function. In [11], an eigenvalue formulation equivalent to the algebraic error was proposed and solved in practice by an efficient Levenberg-Marquardt scheme and a globally optimal Branch-and-Bound. However, Branch-and-Bound has a slow performance.

Convex Relaxation

A different approach that also certifies the optimality of the solution consists of the re-formulation of the original problem as a Quadratically Constrained Quadratic Program (QCQP). These problems are still NP-hard to solve in general; nonetheless we can relax these QCQPs into Semidefinite Relaxation Programs (SDPs) that can be actually solved in polynomial time by off-the-shelf tools, like SDPT3Â [44] or SeDuMiÂ [45].

One of these convex relaxations that have been shown to perform well in practice is known as the Shorâ€™s relaxationÂ [46]. If the relaxation happens to be tight, one can recover the solution to the original problem with an optimality certificate. This relaxation has been shown to remain tight for a wide variety of problems under some conditions and noise regimens, for example in generalized essential matrix estimationÂ [47], nğ‘›n-view triangulationÂ [48] or the Wahba problem with outliersÂ [49], among others.

This was the approach followed inÂ [27], in which the authors posed the RPp as an optimization problem that minimizes an objective function equivalent to the squared epipolar error directly over the rotation and translation spaces. InÂ [15] the author proposed another Shorâ€™s relaxation for the Relative Pose problem that minimizes the squared epipolar error but over the set of normalized essential matrices, leading to a small relaxation that was solved in roughly 6â€‹mâ€‹s6ğ‘šğ‘ 6~{}ms under a C++Â implementation. Although these approaches are faster than those based on BnB, they are still slow for the computer vision standard.

Certifiable algorithms

Although tractable, solving these convex problems from scratch may not be the most efficient way to address them. As an alternative approach one may found the so-called Fast Certifiable Algorithms recently characterized and motivated in [28]. These algorithms typically leverage the existence of an optimality certifier which, given a solution obtained by any means, may be able to certify its optimality. A straightforward approach to get that certificate is through the resolution of the dual problemÂ [46] from scratch, whose optimal cost value always provides a lower bound on the optimal objective for the original problem. In many real-world problem instances this bound is tight, meaning both cost values are the same up to some accuracy and one can certify optimality from it. Under some conditions, we can even extract the solution to our original problem from the solution of the dual, seeÂ e.g.Â [50] for extrinsic calibration of sensors or [31] for registration of points, lines and planes. However, this naive approach would still be as slow as directly solving the problem via its convex relaxation, since for the RPp as posed inÂ [15, 27] both problems are instances of Positive Semidefinite problems (SDP) which can be solved up to arbitrary accuracy in polynomial time.

However, it is also possible to leverage the dual problem to derive a faster certification algorithm. This approach usually leads to a closed-form expression for dual candidates, that is, points that are feasible for the dual problem (within the domain of the dual function). This expression depends on the optimal solution for the original (primal) problem, and if the candidate is indeed feasible, it allows us to certify the optimality of the original solution. For QCQP, the feasibility of the dual candidates is reduced to a spectral analysis of the Hessian of the LagrangianÂ [46]. This has been the approach followed for other problems, for example, rotation averagingÂ [29], point cloud registration with missing dataÂ [30] and outliersÂ [38], pose graph optimizationÂ [51, 52] or SLAMÂ [32, 33, 34].

Our previous workÂ [13] proposed for the first time this kind of optimality certification for the Relative Pose problem. It was shown that the certifiable pipeline works in most problem instances under a wide variety of regimes. Here, we improve this certifier, extend it to consider bad matches, i.e. outliers and evaluate the new proposal against the state-of-the-art solvers for the RPp in extensive experiments on both synthetic and real data.

IV RPp Formulation and Closed-form Dual Candidate

We consider the central calibrated Relative Pose problem in which one seeks the relative rotation ğ‘¹ğ‘¹\bm{R} and translation ğ’•ğ’•\bm{t} between two cameras, given a set of Nğ‘N pair-wise feature correspondences between the two images coming from these distinctive viewpoints, see FigureÂ (1). In this work, the pair-wise correspondences are defined as pairs of (noisy) unit bearing vectors (ğ’‡i,ğ’‡iâ€²)subscriptğ’‡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–â€²(\bm{f}_{i},\bm{f}_{i}^{\prime}) which, if the were a correct correspondence, should point from their respective camera centers towards the same 3D scene point. A traditional way to face this problem is by introducing the essential matrix ğ‘¬=[ğ’•]Ã—â€‹ğ‘¹ğ‘¬subscriptdelimited-[]ğ’•ğ‘¹\bm{E}=[\bm{t}]_{\times}\bm{R}Â [53, 1], a 3Ã—3333\times 3 matrix that encapsulates the geometric information about the relative pose between two calibrated views. The essential matrix relates each pair of corresponding points through the epipolar constraint ğ’‡iTâ€‹ğ‘¬â€‹ğ’‡iâ€²=0superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğ‘¬superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–â€²0\bm{f}_{i}^{T}\bm{E}\bm{f}_{i}^{\prime}=0, provided that the observations are noiseless. With noisy data, however, the equality does not hold and ğ’‡iTâ€‹ğ‘¬â€‹ğ’‡iâ€²=Ïµisuperscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğ‘¬superscriptsubscriptğ’‡ğ‘–â€²subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\bm{f}_{i}^{T}\bm{E}\bm{f}_{i}^{\prime}=\epsilon_{i} defines what is called the normalized algebraic error.

In this work we pose the RPp as an optimization problem over the set of essential matrices that minimizes the squared algebraic error Ïµ2superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\epsilon^{2}, as it has been performed previously in the literature, e.g.,Â [16, 15, 17]. IV-A A Relaxation of the Set of Essential Matrices

For the purpose of this work, a minimal (quadratic) representation is preferred. We leverage the one proposed by Faugeras et al. inÂ [23]:

ğ”¼â‰{ğ‘¬âˆˆâ„3Ã—3|ğ‘¬â€‹ğ‘¬T=[ğ’•]Ã—â€‹[ğ’•]Ã—T,ğ’•Tâ€‹ğ’•=1}.approaches-limitğ”¼conditional-setğ‘¬superscriptâ„33formulae-sequenceğ‘¬superscriptğ‘¬ğ‘‡subscriptdelimited-[]ğ’•superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]ğ’•ğ‘‡superscriptğ’•ğ‘‡ğ’•1\mathbb{E}\doteq\{\bm{E}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3}\;|\;\bm{E}\bm{E}^{T}=[\bm{t}]_{\times}[\bm{t}]_{\times}^{T},\bm{t}^{T}\bm{t}=1\}. (3)

This parameterization, recently exploited by Zhao inÂ [15], features a low number of variables (12)12(12) and constraints (7)7(7), and was proved to be useful in practice. Despite its advantages, this parameterization still does not allow for the development of a fast optimality certifier for the RPp in the fashion of that proposed for problems like Pose Graph Optimization, as in [32, 33].

To overcome this, inÂ [13] we proposed a relaxed version ğ”¼Rsubscriptğ”¼R\mathbb{E}_{\text{R}} of the essential matrix set ğ”¼ğ”¼\mathbb{E} by dropping one the constraints in (3), concretely ğ’†1Tâ€‹ğ’†2+t1â€‹t2=0superscriptsubscriptğ’†1ğ‘‡subscriptğ’†2subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡20\bm{e}_{1}^{T}\bm{e}_{2}+t_{1}t_{2}=0 . This relaxed set is then defined as:

A formal proof of how ğ”¼Rsubscriptğ”¼R\mathbb{E}_{\text{R}}Â inÂ (4) defines a strict superset of ğ”¼ğ”¼\mathbb{E} is provided in Â [13, App.Â B].

We could have discarded any other constraint (except h1subscriptâ„1h_{1}) and hence, obtained other similar yet different relaxed constraint sets. For the sake of simplicity, we will restrict ourselves to the set in (5) and we provide the general form of the certifier in SectionÂ (IV-C). The following development can be trivially adapted to any other relaxation of ğ”¼ğ”¼\mathbb{E}.

Relaxed Formulation of the Relative Pose Problem

With this relaxed set at hand, we define a relaxed version (R) of the original RPp in (O):

fRâ‹†=minğ‘¬âˆˆğ”¼Rvec(ğ‘¬)Tğ‘ªvec(ğ‘¬).f^{\star}_{\text{R}}=\min_{\bm{E}\in\mathbb{E}_{\text{R}}}\operatorname{vec}(\bm{E})^{T}\bm{C}\operatorname{vec}(\bm{E}). (R)

Since problem (R) is a relaxation of (O), the inequality fRâ‹†â‰¤fâ‹†subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†Rsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}_{\text{R}}\leq f^{\star} holds with equality only if the solution to (R) is also an essential matrix, and hence also feasible for (O). Interestingly enough though, we observed that equality holds (fRâ‹†=fâ‹†subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†Rsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}_{\text{R}}=f^{\star}) in many problem instances in practice, meaning that the relaxed problem (R) is very often a tight relaxation of the original problem (O). We have no theoretical proof as to why the behavior above holds so often, and our support to this claim is fundamentally empirical (given by extensive experiments in SectionÂ (VII)).

IV-B Closed-form Expression for Dual Candidates

To derive our certifier, we first re-formulate the relaxed problemÂ (R) as a standard instance of QCQP by writing explicitly the constraints in ğ’Rsubscriptğ’R\mathcal{C}_{\text{R}}. For that, we define the 12-D vector ğ’™=[ğ’†T,ğ’•T]Tğ’™superscriptsuperscriptğ’†ğ‘‡superscriptğ’•ğ‘‡ğ‘‡\bm{x}=[\bm{e}^{T},\bm{t}^{T}]^{T}, with ğ’†=vecâ¡(ğ‘¬)ğ’†vecğ‘¬\bm{e}=\operatorname{vec}(\bm{E}) and hence:

fRâ‹†=minğ’™âˆˆâ„12â¡ğ’™Tâ€‹ğ‘¸â€‹ğ’™subject toÂ â€‹ğ’™Tâ€‹ğ‘¨iâ€‹ğ’™=ci,i=1,â€¦,6formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†Rsubscriptğ’™superscriptâ„12superscriptğ’™ğ‘‡ğ‘¸ğ’™formulae-sequencesubject toÂ superscriptğ’™ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ’™subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1â€¦6\displaystyle f^{\star}_{\text{R}}=\min_{\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{12}}\bm{x}^{T}\bm{Q}\bm{x}\quad\text{subject to }\bm{x}^{T}\bm{A}_{i}\bm{x}=c_{i},i=1,\dots,6 (P-R)

where {ğ‘¨i}i=16superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ‘–16\{\bm{A}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{6} are the 12Ã—12121212\times 12-symmetric corresponding matrix forms of the quadratic constraints, so that hiâ€‹(ğ‘¬,ğ’•)â‰¡ğ’™Tâ€‹ğ‘¨iâ€‹ğ’™âˆ’ci=0,ciâˆˆâ„formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘¬ğ’•superscriptğ’™ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ’™subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–â„h_{i}(\bm{E},\bm{t})\equiv\bm{x}^{T}\bm{A}_{i}\bm{x}-c_{i}=0,c_{i}\in\mathbb{R} with c1=1subscriptğ‘11c_{1}=1 and ci=0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0c_{i}=0 for i=2,â€¦,6ğ‘–2â€¦6i=2,\dots,6, and ğ‘¸ğ‘¸\bm{Q} is the 12Ã—12121212\times 12-symmetric data matrix of compatible dimension with ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} padded with zeros.

Problem (P-R) is exactly equivalent to the relaxed Problem (R). Nonetheless, Problem (P-R) is still a Quadratically Constrained Quadratic Program (QCQP), in general NP-hard to solve. However, it allows us to derive an optimality certifier by exploiting the so-called Lagrangian dual problemÂ [46], that takes the form:

dRâ‹†=maxğ€â¡Î»1subject toÂ â€‹ğ‘´â€‹(ğ€)âª°0formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â‹†Rsubscriptğ€subscriptğœ†1succeeds-or-equalssubject toÂ ğ‘´ğ€0\displaystyle d^{\star}_{\text{R}}=\max_{\bm{\lambda}}\lambda_{1}\quad\text{subject to }\bm{M}(\bm{\lambda})\succeq 0

where ğ‘´â€‹(ğ€)â‰ğ‘¸âˆ’âˆ‘i=16Î»iâ€‹ğ‘¨iapproaches-limitğ‘´ğ€ğ‘¸superscriptsubscriptğ‘–16subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–\bm{M}(\bm{\lambda})\doteq\bm{Q}-\sum_{i=1}^{6}\lambda_{i}\bm{A}_{i} is the so-called Hessian of the Lagrangian and ğ€={Î»i}i=16ğ€superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘–16\bm{\lambda}=\{\lambda_{i}\}_{i=1}^{6} are the Lagrange multipliers. The derivation of the problem is given inÂ [13, App.Â C].

The dual problem (IV-B) presents a relaxation of the primal program (P-R) and hence, its objective cost dRâ€‹(ğ€^)subscriptğ‘‘R^ğ€d_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{\lambda}}) provides us with a lower bound for the objective of the latter fRâ€‹(ğ’™^)subscriptğ‘“R^ğ’™f_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{x}}), principle known as weak dualityÂ [46]. Consider a feasible dual point ğ€^^ğ€\hat{\bm{\lambda}}, i.e. a point that fulfills the constraints required by the dual problem, for (IV-B) and a feasible primal point ğ’™^^ğ’™\hat{\bm{x}} for the relaxed primal in (P-R). The objective costs attain by this pair of primal/dual points (fRâ€‹(ğ’™^),dRâ€‹(ğ€^)subscriptğ‘“R^ğ’™subscriptğ‘‘R^ğ€f_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{x}}),d_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{\lambda}}), respectively) are related by the following chain of inequalities:

dRâ€‹(ğ€^)â‰¤adRâ‹†â‰¤bfRâ‹†â‰¤cfâ‹†â‰¤dfâ€‹(ğ‘¬^),superscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘‘R^ğ€subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â‹†Rsuperscriptğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†Rsuperscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘“â‹†superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘“^ğ‘¬d_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{\lambda}})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle a}}{{\leq}}d^{\star}_{\text{R}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle b}}{{\leq}}f^{\star}_{\text{R}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle c}}{{\leq}}f^{\star}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle d}}{{\leq}}f(\hat{\bm{E}}), (6)

where (a) and (d) hold by definition of optimality, (c) stands since (P-R) is a relaxation of (O) and (b) holds because, at the same time, the dual problem is a relaxation of the primal (P-R) (weak duality).

FromÂ (6) we can see that the dual problem allows to certify if a given primal feasible point ğ’™^^ğ’™\hat{\bm{x}} is indeed optimal. If for a pair of primal/dual feasible points we have that fRâ€‹(ğ’™^)=dRâ€‹(ğ€^)subscriptğ‘“R^ğ’™subscriptğ‘‘R^ğ€f_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{x}})=d_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{\lambda}}) (up to some accuracy), then the chain of inequalities becomes tight and fâ‹†=fRâ€‹(ğ’™^)superscriptğ‘“â‹†subscriptğ‘“R^ğ’™f^{\star}=f_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{x}}), which shows that ğ’™^^ğ’™\hat{\bm{x}} is the optimal solution. In these cases, we say that there is strong duality and that the duality gap fRâ‹†âˆ’dRâ‹†subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†Rsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â‹†Rf^{\star}_{\text{R}}-d^{\star}_{\text{R}} is zero.

Although the dual problem (IV-B) is a SDP and can be solved by off-the-shelf solvers (e.g., SeDuMiÂ [45] or SDPT3Â [44]) in polynomial time, a faster optimality verification can be derived. This certification relies on a closed-form expression for dual candidates ğ€^^ğ€\hat{\bm{\lambda}}, thus avoiding the resolution of the SDP from scratch. This closed-form expression is derived from the requirement that every primal solution ğ’™^^ğ’™\hat{\bm{x}} must fulfill the KKT conditionsÂ [46, Sec.Â 5.5].

Theorem IV.1 (Verification of OptimalityÂ [13, Th.Â 5.2]).

Given a putative primal solution ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\bm{x}} for Problem (P-R), if there exists a solution ğ›Œ^^ğ›Œ\hat{\bm{\lambda}} to the linear system

ğ‘±â€‹(ğ’™^)â€‹ğ€^=ğ‘¸â€‹ğ’™^,ğ‘±^ğ’™^ğ€ğ‘¸^ğ’™\bm{J}(\hat{\bm{x}})\hat{\bm{\lambda}}=\bm{Q}\hat{\bm{x}}, (7)

and ğŒâ€‹(ğ›Œ^)âª°0succeeds-or-equalsğŒbold-^ğ›Œ0\bm{M}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}\succeq 0, then we have strong duality and the putative solution ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\bm{x}} is indeed optimal. Here ğ‰â€‹(ğ±^)âˆˆâ„12Ã—6ğ‰^ğ±superscriptâ„126\bm{J}(\hat{\bm{x}})\in\mathbb{R}^{12\times 6} is the full-rank Jacobian of the constraints evaluated at the potentially optimal point ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\bm{x}} for the relaxed problem (P-R) whose explicit form can be found in [13] and in the Online ResourceÂ SectionÂ (A).

The restriction of Theorem (IV.1) to essential matrices is summarized as follows:

Corollary IV.1.1.

[13, Cor.Â 5.2.1] Given a potentially optimal solution ğ„^^ğ„\hat{\bm{E}} for problem (O) and its equivalent form ğ±^=[vec(ğ„^)T,ğ­^T]T\hat{\bm{x}}=[\operatorname{vec}(\hat{\bm{E}})^{T},\hat{\bm{t}}^{T}]^{T} where ğ­^^ğ­\hat{\bm{t}} is the associated translation vector, if there exists a unique solution ğ›Œ^^ğ›Œ\hat{\bm{\lambda}} to the linear system in (7) and it is dual feasible (i.e. ğŒâ€‹(ğ›Œ^)âª°0succeeds-or-equalsğŒbold-^ğ›Œ0\bm{M}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}\succeq 0), then we can state that: (1) strong duality holds between problems (P-R) and (IV-B); (2) the relaxation carried out in (P-R) is tight; and (3) the potentially optimal solution ğ„^^ğ„\hat{\bm{E}} is optimal for both (P-R) and (O).

We want to point out that Theorem (IV.1) and Corollary (IV.1.1) can only either certify the given primal solution is indeed optimal, or it is inconclusive about its optimality. The reason for the latter is associated either with a suboptimal solution and/or a loose relaxation (either the one carried out for the primal in (P-R) and/or the one for the dual in (IV-B)).

Remark 1.

In this work we propose a set of six relaxations of the original problem (O) obtained by dropping only one constraint from the original set in (3). These relaxations allow to compute a unique dual candidate ğ›Œ^^ğ›Œ\hat{\bm{\lambda}} in closed-form from (7) since the Jacobian is full rank. We can, nevertheless, discard more constraints and still derive closed-form expressions for dual candidates and the associated fast certification algorithms akin to TheoremÂ (IV.1). These problems, though, are looser relaxations of the originalÂ (O), and their dual problems may not provide with a tight lower bound, that is, the certifier associated to that relaxation will not be able to certify the optimal solution to the original problem. While the computation cost for these smaller certifiers could be potentially lower (the linear system in (7) has fewer unknowns ğ›Œ^^ğ›Œ\hat{\bm{\lambda}}), we do not know a priori whether any of these relaxations perform well in terms of certification of essential matrices. Therefore, the tightest relaxations for the parameterization of the essential matrix set in (3) that still assure closed-form expressions with unique solution for dual candidates are obtained by dropping only one constraint of the set.

IV-C Family of Certifiers from different Closed-form Dual Candidates

The employed relaxation of the feasible set of essential matrices in (5) was necessary in order to assure the uniqueness of the Lagrange multipliers. We can, nevertheless, obtain similar yet different relaxations by dropping one of the other five different constraints in ğ‘¬â€‹ğ‘¬Tğ‘¬superscriptğ‘¬ğ‘‡\bm{E}\bm{E}^{T}. These relaxations would yield distinct optimality certifiers for the same problem whose candidates to Lagrange multipliers are also computed in closed-form. If (at least) one of them fulfills the conditions for optimality (see Theorem (IV.1)), then the solution is optimal and the associated underlying relaxation is tight. On the other hand, if none of them fulfill these conditions, this does not imply that the solution is suboptimal: all the relaxations could be not tight at the same time as well. In its general form, we can write the closed-form expression for the multipliers as:

ğ‘¸â€‹ğ’™^=âˆ‘i=27Î¸iâ€‹Î»^iâ€‹ğ‘¨iâ€‹ğ’™^+Î»^1â€‹ğ‘¨1â€‹ğ’™^=ğ‘±â€‹(ğ’™^,ğœ½)â€‹ğ€^,ğ‘¸^ğ’™superscriptsubscriptğ‘–27subscriptğœƒğ‘–subscript^ğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–^ğ’™subscript^ğœ†1subscriptğ‘¨1^ğ’™ğ‘±^ğ’™ğœ½^ğ€\bm{Q}\hat{\bm{x}}=\sum_{i=2}^{7}\theta_{i}\hat{\lambda}_{i}\bm{A}_{i}\hat{\bm{x}}+\hat{\lambda}_{1}\bm{A}_{1}\hat{\bm{x}}=\bm{J}(\hat{\bm{x}},\bm{\theta})\hat{\bm{\lambda}}, (8)

where Î¸iâˆˆ{0,1},i=2,â€¦,7formulae-sequencesubscriptğœƒğ‘–01ğ‘–2â€¦7\theta_{i}\in\{0,1\},i=2,\dots,7, with âˆ‘iÎ¸i=5subscriptğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–5\sum_{i}\theta_{i}=5 and ğœ½â‰[Î¸2,â€¦,Î¸7]approaches-limitğœ½subscriptğœƒ2â€¦subscriptğœƒ7\bm{\theta}\doteq[\theta_{2},\dots,\theta_{7}]. The variable Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i} â€œactivatesâ€œ the iğ‘–i-th constraint (with matrix form ğ’™Tâ€‹ğ‘¨iâ€‹ğ’™=ci,i=2,â€¦,7formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ’™ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ’™subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–2â€¦7\bm{x}^{T}\bm{A}_{i}\bm{x}=c_{i},\ i=2,\dots,7) when it is equal to one. In other terms, for any combination of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}, one of the constraints in (3) (except hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i}) is always deactivated. The column of the full Jacobian associated with that multiplier is zero for any point ğ’™^^ğ’™\hat{\bm{x}} and it can be dropped. Hence, the matrix ğ‘±â€‹(ğ’™^,ğœ½)ğ‘±^ğ’™ğœ½\bm{J}(\hat{\bm{x}},\bm{\theta}) has always linearly independent columns (following a similar proof to that provided inÂ [13, App.Â D]).

In the worst case, we compute six different certifiers: solve Equation (8) with the six different combinations for ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}); and six eigenvalues of a 3Ã—3333\times 3 matrix (closed-form) and six eigenvalues of a 9Ã—9999\times 9 matrix. In practice, however, this is not necessary. FigureÂ (3) depicts the cumulative percentage of cases with certified optimal solutions (Y-axis) as a function of the number of computed certifiers (X-axis) for different level of noise, parallax and Field of View (SectionÂ (VII) explains the details about the experiments). Note that at least 99%percent9999\% of optimal cases are detected with only 222 certifiers for most of the problems (except narrow field of views, FOV), while the 100%percent100100\% is detected with 444 certifiers. For narrow FOVÂ 70âˆ’90â€‹degrees7090degrees70-90\ \text{degrees}, however, one may need to compute all of them.

This redundant estimation of potential dual candidates increases the computation time required by the verification stage. We observe that estimating the Lagrange multipliers and checking the spectral conditions takes approximately the same amount of time that the initialization by the 8-pt algorithm (singular vector estimation and projection). We can, of course, compute only one certifier. As it is shown in FigureÂ (3), we will still detect more than 95%percent9595\% of the optimal cases in general. The choice is left to the user and the application.

IV-D Exploiting structure: separating and ordering

Once the candidate has been computed, TheoremÂ (IV.1) requires to analyze the eigenvalues of the Hessian of the Lagrangian ğ‘´â€‹(ğ€^)ğ‘´bold-^ğ€\bm{M}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}. This matrix is block-diagonal with two (squared) blocks ğ‘´ğ’†â€‹(ğ€^),ğ‘´ğ’•â€‹(ğ€^)superscriptğ‘´ğ’†bold-^ğ€superscriptğ‘´ğ’•bold-^ğ€{\bm{M}^{\bm{e}}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}},{\bm{M}^{\bm{t}}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}} of size 9 and 3, respectively. Both blocks must be positive semi-definite (PSD) for the full Hessian to be PSD, since the spectrum of a block-diagonal matrix is the union of the spectra of its blocks. We can then translate the original condition ğ‘´â€‹(ğ€^)âª°0succeeds-or-equalsğ‘´bold-^ğ€0\bm{M}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}\succeq 0 to the two smaller conditions ğ‘´ğ’†â€‹(ğ€^)âª°0succeeds-or-equalssuperscriptğ‘´ğ’†bold-^ğ€0{\bm{M}^{\bm{e}}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}}\succeq 0 and ğ‘´ğ’•â€‹(ğ€^)âª°0succeeds-or-equalssuperscriptğ‘´ğ’•bold-^ğ€0{\bm{M}^{\bm{t}}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}}\succeq 0, which must hold at the same time. Further, and although our justification here is purely empirical, we observe that those cases for which the Hessian was not PSD were associated with ğ‘´ğ’•â€‹(ğ€^)superscriptğ‘´ğ’•bold-^ğ€{\bm{M}^{\bm{t}}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}} being not PSD. Therefore and in practice, we check first the PSD condition for this 3Ã—3333\times 3 matrix (whose eigenvalues have a closed-form expression). If it is fulfilled, we then verify the condition for ğ‘´ğ’†â€‹(ğ€^)superscriptğ‘´ğ’†bold-^ğ€{\bm{M}^{\bm{e}}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}}. If both blocks are PSD, then the Hessian is PSD.

With these improvements at hand, we can now provide the optimality certification algorithm in AlgorithmÂ (1). To universalize the Algorithm, let us denote by ğ’™^=[vec(ğ‘¬^)T,ğ’•^T]T\hat{\bm{x}}=[\operatorname{vec}(\hat{\bm{E}})^{T},\hat{\bm{t}}^{T}]^{T} the feasible solution for (P-R) or for (O). Further, for any ğ‘¬^âˆˆğ”¼^ğ‘¬ğ”¼\hat{\bm{E}}\in\mathbb{E}, the attained objective value in (O) (fâ€‹(ğ‘¬^))ğ‘“^ğ‘¬\big{(}f(\hat{\bm{E}})\big{)} agrees with the objective value in (P-R) (fRâ€‹(ğ’™^))subscriptğ‘“R^ğ’™\big{(}f_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{x}})\big{)} since ğ”¼âŠ‚ğ”¼Rğ”¼subscriptğ”¼R\mathbb{E}\subset\mathbb{E}_{\text{R}}; hence we employ fRâ€‹(ğ’™^)subscriptğ‘“R^ğ’™f_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{x}}) to denote the corresponding objective value in both cases without confusion. Recall that our certification has two possible outcomes, either Positive (the solution is optimal) or unknown (the certification is inconclusive). From a practical point of view, we write the conditions ğ‘´ğ’†â€‹(ğ€^),ğ‘´ğ’•â€‹(ğ€^)âª°0succeeds-or-equalssuperscriptğ‘´ğ’†bold-^ğ€superscriptğ‘´ğ’•bold-^ğ€0{\bm{M}^{\bm{e}}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}},{\bm{M}^{\bm{t}}\bm{(\hat{\lambda})}}\succeq 0 as their smallest eigenvalues Î¼t,Î¼Esubscriptğœ‡ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‡ğ¸\mu_{t},\mu_{E} being greater than a negative threshold Ï„Î¼subscriptğœğœ‡\tau_{\mu}. Further, while our closed-form certifier assumes that strong duality holds, due to rounding errors the dual gap fRâ€‹(ğ’™^)âˆ’dRâ€‹(ğ€^)subscriptğ‘“R^ğ’™subscriptğ‘‘R^ğ€f_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{x}})-d_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{\lambda}}) may not be exactly zero. We assure strong duality by applying a (positive) threshold Ï„gapsubscriptğœgap\tau_{\text{gap}} to the absolute value of the dual gap |fRâ€‹(ğ’™^)âˆ’dRâ€‹(ğ€^)|subscriptğ‘“R^ğ’™subscriptğ‘‘R^ğ€|f_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{x}})-d_{\text{R}}(\hat{\bm{\lambda}})|, which allow us to accommodate numerical errors. In practice, we fix the tolerances to Ï„Î¼=âˆ’0.02subscriptğœğœ‡0.02\tau_{\mu}=-0.02 and Ï„gap=10âˆ’14subscriptğœgapsuperscript1014\tau_{\text{gap}}=10^{-14}. If any of the minimum eigenvalues are negative and/or the dual gap is greater than zero (considering the tolerance in both cases), the certification procedure is inconclusive.

V Proposed Fast Certifiable Pipeline

Rather than solving the original problem (O) via its convex SDP relaxation, in this work we propose to solve the RPp through an iterative method that respects the intrinsic nature of the essential matrix set, but comes with no optimality guarantees, and to certify a-posteriori the optimality of the solution leveraging our fast optimality certifier in AlgorithmÂ (1). Current iterative methods work well and usually converge to the global optima in addition to be faster than the methods employed in convex programming, e.g., Interior Point Methods (IPM). Following, we enumerate and briefly explain the three major stages in which the proposed pipeline is separated:

  1. 1.

    Initialization: We start by generating an initial guess with any standard algorithm, e.g. the 8-pt algorithmÂ [1].

  2. 2.

    Refinement (optimization on manifold): We seek the solution to the original primal problem (O) by refining the initial guess with a local iterative method that operates within the essential matrix manifold â„³ğ‘¬subscriptâ„³ğ‘¬\mathcal{M}_{\bm{E}} (always fulfilling constraints).

    ğ‘¬^=argâ€‹minğ‘¬âˆˆâ„³ğ‘¬vec(ğ‘¬)Tğ‘ªvec(ğ‘¬).\displaystyle\hat{\bm{E}}=\operatornamewithlimits{arg\,min}_{\bm{E}\in\mathcal{M}_{\bm{E}}}\operatorname{vec}(\bm{E})^{T}\bm{C}\operatorname{vec}(\bm{E}). (9)

    Recall that the matrix ğ‘¸âˆˆğ•Š+12ğ‘¸superscriptsubscriptğ•Š12\bm{Q}\in\mathbb{S}_{+}^{12} is the data matrix ğ‘ªâˆˆğ•Š+9ğ‘ªsuperscriptsubscriptğ•Š9\bm{C}\in\mathbb{S}_{+}^{9} padded with zeros.

  3. 3.

    Verification of optimality: The candidate solution ğ‘¬^^ğ‘¬\hat{\bm{E}} returned by the iterative method can be certified as the global optimum with the proposed Algorithm (1) if the underlying dual problemÂ (IV-B) is tight.

Note that the above-mentioned pipeline estimates the essential matrix, which encodes the relative pose. Both the rotation and translation up-to-scale can be extracted from it by any classic computer vision algorithmÂ [1].

V-A Refinement of the initial estimation: optimization on manifold

Riemannian optimization toolboxes decouple the optimization problem into manifold (domain), problem description and solvers, thus making it quite straightforward to implement an iterative solver for (9) as proposed above.

Domain: Current tools for optimization on manifolds, such as manoptÂ [54], provide a wide variety on pre-defined manifolds and operators which alleviate the programming effort required for its use. Although the implementation is pretty simple when the employed manifold is supplied by the tool (as it happens inÂ [13]), this is not always the case. In those situations, the user needs to either implement it or employ a different but equivalent parameterization of the manifold whose components are provided by the library.

In the RPp the essential matrix manifold can be simplified in most cases to the direct product space SOâ€‹(3)Ã—ğ’®2SO3superscriptğ’®2\text{SO}(3)\times\mathcal{S}^{2} by leveraging the standard definition given in (2). This product is composed of two well-known spaces, SOâ€‹(3),ğ’®2SO3superscriptğ’®2\text{SO}(3),\mathcal{S}^{2}, which are usually provided by the optimization toolboxes. In any case, they can be also easily implemented, so is their direct product (see e.g. [16]).

Despite its simplicity, however, the above-mentioned product is indeed a four-fold covering of the essential matrix manifold â„³ğ‘¬subscriptâ„³ğ‘¬\mathcal{M}_{\bm{E}} (ambiguity which is well-known [1, 27]). Nevertheless, this does not suppose a major issue when we are only required to estimate one single essential matrix at a time (manifold optimization); we refer the reader to [26] for a full characterization of â„³ğ‘¬subscriptâ„³ğ‘¬\mathcal{M}_{\bm{E}} and to [55] for a detailed explanation of those cases in which this simplification cannot be employed directly (manifold statistics).

Although simple, this re-parameterization of the search space requires to adapt the objective function to the new set of variables, which may not be straightforward. Further, we also need to provide the gradient and the Hessian (if the chosen solver employs second-order information) w.r.t. this new parameterization. Thanks to the decoupling of the problem into domain and model description, the well-known nature of the rotation and sphere groups and the simplification of the product of manifolds, there exist simple relations between the ambient gradient and Hessian-vector product and their Riemannian counterparts. First, let the objective function fâ€‹(ğ‘¹,ğ’•)ğ‘“ğ‘¹ğ’•f(\bm{R},\bm{t}) be defined in terms of the rotation and translation (ğ‘¹,ğ’•)ğ‘¹ğ’•(\bm{R},\bm{t}) (to be defined later). The Riemannian gradient gradâ€‹fâ€‹(ğ‘¹,ğ’•)gradğ‘“ğ‘¹ğ’•\text{grad}f(\bm{R},\bm{t}) and Hessian-vector product Hessğ‘¹,ğ’•â€‹fâ€‹(ğ‘¹,ğ’•)subscriptHessğ‘¹ğ’•ğ‘“ğ‘¹ğ’•\text{Hess}_{\bm{R},\bm{t}}f(\bm{R},\bm{t}) defined on the space SOâ€‹(3)Ã—ğ’®2SO3superscriptğ’®2\text{SO}(3)\times\mathcal{S}^{2} can be treated element-wise, that is:

Solver: We choose here an iterative truncated-Newton Riemannian trust-region (RTR) solverÂ [42]. RTR has shown beforeÂ [51, 52] a very good trade-off between a large basin of convergence and superlinear convergence speed.

In order to speed up the converge of the algorithm and inspired by [51] and [52], we propose a suitable Hessian preconditioner for the relative pose problem which is proved through extensive experiments in Section (VII) to reduce the number of iterations required by the solver to converge. The use of a preconditioner is based on the dependence of the convergence rate of the conjugate method when solving the linear system ğ‘¨â€‹ğ’™=ğ’ƒğ‘¨ğ’™ğ’ƒ\bm{A}\bm{x}=\bm{b} with the condition number of the matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨\bm{A}. The Riemannian preconditioner ğ‘·ğ‘·\bm{P} must be a linear, symmetric and positive definite operator from the tangent space of the manifold to itself. We propose to use the preconditioning operator similar to Jacobi and of the form

ğ‘·â€‹(ğ‘¼)â‰ProjSOâ€‹(3)Ã—ğ’®2â€‹(1Î±â€‹ğ‘¼),approaches-limitğ‘·ğ‘¼subscriptProjSO3superscriptğ’®21ğ›¼ğ‘¼\bm{P}(\bm{U})\doteq\text{Proj}_{\text{SO}(3)\times\mathcal{S}^{2}}(\frac{1}{\alpha}\bm{U}), (22)

with Î±ğ›¼\alpha is a positive scalar related to the eigenvalues of the data matrix ğ‘ªğ‘ª\bm{C}. Since the data matrix cannot be zero and it is PSD, this preconditioner is, by definition, linear, symmetric and positive definite. It is also defined from and onto the tangent space since ğ‘¼ğ‘¼\bm{U} belongs to this tangent space and the result is projected onto the tangent space. We propose the value for Î±=Î»1+Î»2+Î»3ğ›¼subscriptğœ†1subscriptğœ†2subscriptğœ†3\alpha=\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}+\lambda_{3}, which are the three largest eigenvalues of the data matrix ğ‘ªğ‘ª\bm{C}. Although this preconditioner is heuristic, it is showcased later on SectionÂ (VII) that it does reduce the computation time for the iteration method, specially when the number of correspondences is large, as it is usually the case in practical applications.

VI Robust Resolution of the Relative Pose Problem

SectionÂ (V) outlines a complete certifiable pipeline for the essential matrix estimation whose core lies on the local refinement stage. This refinement is, however, very sensitive to bad correspondences, i.e. outliers; in the presence of only one outlier, the solution will be biased. Instead of embedding and adjusting our pipeline into a RANSAC paradigm, we leverage the tools known as Graduated Non-convexity (GNC)Â [36] and the Black-Rangarajan dualityÂ [37] to detect and discard outliers. This scheme has been previously employed, see e.g.Â [15, 39], showing that it is able to estimate better solutions than RANSAC-based paradigms, specially for problem instances where the percentage of outliers is large. In this Section we summarize this scheme and specialized it for the Tukeyâ€™s biweight loss functionÂ [37]. The approach is extensible to other functions, some of them can be also found in previous works (e.g., Welsch function inÂ [15] and Truncated Least Square and Geman-McClure inÂ [39]).

We first introduce a robust loss function Ïâ€‹(âˆ™)ğœŒâˆ™\rho(\bullet) into the cost function fâ€‹(ğ‘¬)ğ‘“ğ‘¬f(\bm{E}) of the original problem (O). The robust variant of (O) is written as

minğ‘¬âˆˆğ”¼â€‹âˆ‘i=1NÏâ€‹(Ïµi),subscriptğ‘¬ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğœŒsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\min_{\bm{E}\in\mathbb{E}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\rho\big{(}\epsilon_{i}\big{)}, (23)

where recall that Ïµisubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon_{i} was the epipolar error for the iğ‘–i-th correspondence.

It is known that the chosen loss function ÏğœŒ\rho has a great impact on the performance of the algorithm. Thus, although convex functions exist, such as Huber or â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}, these have a low breakdown point and are still sensible to gross outliers; non-convex loss functions are usually preferred. Following the approach inÂ [39], we define the Tukeyâ€™s biweight loss function Ïâ€‹(âˆ™)ğœŒâˆ™\rho(\bullet) in terms of a threshold cÂ¯âˆˆâ„Â¯ğ‘â„\overline{c}\in\mathbb{R} as

ÏcÂ¯â€‹(r)={r2cÂ¯2âˆ’(r2cÂ¯2)2+13â€‹(r2cÂ¯2)3,|r|â‰¤cÂ¯13,Â otherwiseÂ ,subscriptğœŒÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Ÿcasesotherwisesuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptÂ¯ğ‘2superscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptÂ¯ğ‘2213superscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptÂ¯ğ‘23ğ‘ŸÂ¯ğ‘otherwise13Â otherwiseÂ \rho_{\overline{c}}(r)=\begin{cases}&\frac{r^{2}}{\overline{c}^{2}}-\Big{(}\frac{r^{2}}{\overline{c}^{2}}\Big{)}^{2}+\frac{1}{3}\Big{(}\frac{r^{2}}{\overline{c}^{2}}\Big{)}^{3},\quad|r|\leq\overline{c}\\ &\frac{1}{3},\quad\text{ otherwise }\end{cases}, (24)

where cÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\overline{c} determines the shape of the function, as it is shown in FigureÂ (4(a)). The variable cÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\overline{c} thus controls what points we are considering as inliers; for cÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\overline{c} large, all the points are considered as such (including outliers), while in the opposite extreme, only these points with very low residuals are considered as inliers.

Since the loss function is non-convex, Problem (23) is prone to get trapped in local minima. The first step towards the efficient resolution of Problem (23) leverages the Black-Rangarajan duality between robust and line processesÂ [37]. By introducing a set of slack variables or weights, wiâˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–01w_{i}\in[0,1], one for each correspondence and an outlier process term Î¨cÂ¯â€‹(wi)subscriptÎ¨Â¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\Psi_{\overline{c}}(w_{i}), we can re-formulate any robust estimation problem as

minğ‘¬âˆˆğ”¼,wiâˆˆ[0,1],i=1,â€¦â€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nwiâ€‹Ïµi2+Î¨cÂ¯â€‹(wi).subscriptğ‘¬ğ”¼formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–01ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2subscriptÎ¨Â¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\bm{E}\in\mathbb{E},\\ w_{i}\in[0,1],i=1,\dots N\end{subarray}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_{i}\epsilon_{i}^{2}+\Psi_{\overline{c}}(w_{i}). (25)

The term Î¨cÂ¯â€‹(wi)subscriptÎ¨Â¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\Psi_{\overline{c}}(w_{i}) that penalizes the weight wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i} usually admits an analytical expression for most common loss functions (see [37]).

However, (25) is still non-convex. To avoid this behavior, we leverage the tool known as Graduated Non-convexity (GNC) that allows to optimize a generic non-convex function by solving a sequence of surrogate problems of increasing non-convexity. This is achieved by introducing a surrogate function ÏÎ¼subscriptğœŒğœ‡\rho_{\mu} controlled by a parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu such that, for some Î¼ğœ‡\mu the function is convex and, in the limit, we obtain the original non-convex function Ïâ€‹(âˆ™)ğœŒâˆ™\rho(\bullet). We start by solving the initial convex problem and update the parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu, thus increasing the non-convexity of the next problem to solve, till the original problem is attained. The variable estimated for the iğ‘–i-th problem is employed as initialization for the (i+1)ğ‘–1(i+1)-th problem.

For the Tukeyâ€™s biweight function in (24), the surrogate function with the control parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu is given as

ÏcÂ¯â€‹(r,Î¼)={r2Î¼â€‹cÂ¯2âˆ’(r2Î¼â€‹cÂ¯2)2+13â€‹(r2Î¼â€‹cÂ¯2)3,|r|â‰¤Î¼â€‹cÂ¯13,Â otherwiseÂ .subscriptğœŒÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğœ‡casesotherwisesuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğœ‡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘2superscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğœ‡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘2213superscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğœ‡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘23ğ‘Ÿğœ‡Â¯ğ‘otherwise13Â otherwiseÂ \rho_{\overline{c}}(r,\mu)=\begin{cases}&\frac{r^{2}}{\mu\overline{c}^{2}}-\Big{(}\frac{r^{2}}{\mu\overline{c}^{2}}\Big{)}^{2}+\frac{1}{3}\Big{(}\frac{r^{2}}{\mu\overline{c}^{2}}\Big{)}^{3},\quad|r|\leq\sqrt{\mu}\overline{c}\\ &\frac{1}{3},\quad\text{ otherwise }\end{cases}. (26)

For large Î¼ğœ‡\mu, the function ÏcÂ¯â€‹(r,Î¼)subscriptğœŒÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğœ‡\rho_{\overline{c}}(r,\mu) is convex and returns the original function (24) when Î¼=1ğœ‡1\mu=1 (see FigureÂ (4(b))). The outlier process Î¨cÂ¯â€‹(wi)subscriptÎ¨Â¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\Psi_{\overline{c}}(w_{i}) in (25) for any GNC surrogate with parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu is defined as

Î¨cÂ¯â€‹(wi,Î¼)=Î¼â€‹cÂ¯23â€‹(1âˆ’wi)2â€‹(1+2â€‹wi).subscriptÎ¨Â¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğœ‡ğœ‡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘23superscript1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–212subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\Psi_{\overline{c}}(w_{i},\mu)=\frac{\mu\overline{c}^{2}}{3}(1-\sqrt{w_{i}})^{2}(1+2\sqrt{w_{i}}). (27)

Overview of the Robust Estimation

With these tools at hand, we are now able to solve the non-convex problem (23). At each outer iteration, we update the control parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu and optimize

minğ‘¬âˆˆğ”¼â€‹âˆ‘i=1NÏcÂ¯â€‹(Ïµi,Î¼).subscriptğ‘¬ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğœŒÂ¯ğ‘subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–ğœ‡\min_{\bm{E}\in\mathbb{E}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\rho_{\overline{c}}\big{(}\epsilon_{i},\mu\big{)}. (28)

with ÏcÂ¯â€‹(Ïµi,Î¼)subscriptğœŒÂ¯ğ‘subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–ğœ‡\rho_{\overline{c}}(\epsilon_{i},\mu) given by (26). By the Black-Rangarajan duality, we re-formulate this surrogate problem as the joint optimization over ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E} and {wi}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘\{w_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N}:

minğ‘¬âˆˆğ”¼,wiâˆˆ[0,1],i=1,â€¦â€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nwiâ€‹Ïµi2+Î¨cÂ¯â€‹(wi,Î¼).subscriptğ‘¬ğ”¼formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–01ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2subscriptÎ¨Â¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğœ‡\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\bm{E}\in\mathbb{E},\\ w_{i}\in[0,1],i=1,\dots N\end{subarray}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_{i}\epsilon_{i}^{2}+\Psi_{\overline{c}}(w_{i},\mu). (29)

Problem (29) is actually solved by alternating optimization. At each inner iteration, we optimize over ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E} with the previous {wi}subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\{w_{i}\} and then, we optimize over {wi}subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\{w_{i}\} with fixed ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E}. See that in the first optimization, the second term in (29) does not depend on ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E} and can be dropped. Hence, this first problem is the weighted version of the non-minimal presented in (9). The optimization over {wi}subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\{w_{i}\} with fixed ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E} can be solved in closed-form for the loss function considered here. The weight wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i} is computed as:

wi={0Ïµi2Î¼â€‹cÂ¯2>1(1âˆ’Ïµi2Î¼â€‹cÂ¯2)2Â otherwiseÂ .subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–cases0superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2ğœ‡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘21superscript1superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2ğœ‡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘22Â otherwiseÂ w_{i}=\begin{cases}0&\quad\frac{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}{\mu\overline{c}^{2}}>1\\ \Big{(}1-\frac{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}{\mu\overline{c}^{2}}\Big{)}^{2}&\quad\text{ otherwise }\end{cases}. (30)

Note that wiâˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–01w_{i}\in[0,1] since Ïµi2Î¼â€‹cÂ¯2â‰¥0superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2ğœ‡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘20\frac{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}{\mu\overline{c}^{2}}\geq 0.

This process, which is summarized in AlgorithmÂ (2), is repeated for decreasing values of Î¼ğœ‡\mu until it is equal to one. This decreasing rate is given by the parameter Ï„Î¼>1.0subscriptğœğœ‡1.0\tau_{\mu}>1.0. Although AlgorithmÂ (2) only requires as input the set of correspondences, we can also provide the initialization for the local, iterative optimization algorithm that updates the variable ğ‘¬ğ‘¬\bm{E} and the initial weights associated the correspondences.

Implementation details: In practice, we fix the rate for Î¼ğœ‡\mu in Ï„Î¼=1.10subscriptğœğœ‡1.10\tau_{\mu}=1.10 and stop the algorithm if the difference between two consecutive cost values for outer iterations lies below 10âˆ’6superscript10610^{-6}. The same threshold is employed to break the inner loop, although it does not stop the estimation. We allow two iterations for the inner loop and 500 for the outer. We define the shape parameter as cÂ¯2=10âˆ’5superscriptÂ¯ğ‘2superscript105\overline{c}^{2}=10^{-5} and consider as inlier any correspondence whose weight is greater than Ï„w=0.9subscriptğœğ‘¤0.9\tau_{w}=0.9. In the last step, we refine the estimated essential matrix only with the set of inliers. To avoid ill-posed problems, we required that at least there exist N0=12subscriptğ‘012N_{0}=12 inliers. We apply our certifier to this last problem and solution defined only with the inliers.

A fast, C++Â implementation of our proposal is publicly available in
https://github.com/mergarsal/FastCertRelPose.git. Bindings for matlab and Python are also provided. As a by-product of our contribution, we also release a lightweight template library in
https://github.com/mergarsal/GNCSO.git
for the robust algorithm in (2), that currently111Date of this document includes Tukeyâ€™s biweight, Welsch (Leclerc), Geman-McClure and TLS loss functions, and admits any non-minimal o minimal solver for the variable estimation step. This library also wraps around the Optimization library by Rosen et al. [52] that allows to perform local optimization on Riemannian manifold and convex spaces.

VII Experimental Validation

In this last Section, we empirically showcase the utility of the proposed certifiable pipeline and the improvements presented in this work through an extensive set of experiments on both synthetic (Section (VII-B)) and real data (Section (VII-C)). Before that, we compare the proposed certifiable pipeline against the state-of-the-art certifiable approaches proposed for the RPp (Section (VII-A)). All the experiments were performed in the same machine (PC) with: CPU intel i7-4702MQ, 2.2GHz and RAM 8 GB.

VII-A Comparison against certifiable solvers

In this Section we compare the performance in terms of accuracy and computational cost of the proposed solver against the state-of-the-art certifiable approaches.

As we introduce in SectionÂ (II), certifiable solvers for the RPp exist that rely on Branch-and-Bound optimization and convex relaxations, the latter solved via Interior Point Algorithms (IPM) with off-the-shelf tools. The first set of solvers present worst-case exponential time complexity due to their exploration of the feasible set. As it has been reported in the original papers [12, 11], and recent works [15], this leads to computational times of seconds or even minutes. We will not examine further this type of solvers since the other approaches based on convex relaxations have been shown to be faster with polynomial time complexity. The complexity depends on the number of variables and constraints, which can be empirically observed when comparing, for example, [27] (404040 variables and 536536536 constraints) and [15] (121212 variables and 777 constraints). We perform a set of experiments with both solvers under a matlab implementation (using SDPT3Â [44] as IPM), and observe that [27] takes 1-2 seconds, while [15] remains under 0.5 seconds. For the same set of experiments and under a matlab implementation, our proposal roughly takes 505050 milliseconds (including variable estimation).

From the above discussion we can derive that the faster certifiable solver is the SDP proposed in [15]. We next perform a comparison against this SDP; we employ the released code by the author 222 https://github.com/jizhaox/npt-pose . We perform a set of experiments on synthetic data (see SectionÂ (VII-B1) for a detailed explanation of the data generation). We observe, as it was pointed out by the author, that the relaxation does not perform always well with low number of correspondences and/or large noise. For the sake of clarity, we restrict the noise to Ïƒ={0.5,1.0,2.0,2.5}ğœ0.51.02.02.5\sigma=\{0.5,1.0,2.0,2.5\} pixels and number of correspondences in N={50,70,100,150,200}ğ‘5070100150200N=\{50,70,100,150,200\}; for each configuration, we generate 500500500 random problem instances. We measure the distance between the returned rotation matrices w.r.t. the ground truth in terms of geodesic distance. FigureÂ (5(a)) shows the mean errors for each configuration of parameters. We also measure the distance between the solutions w.r.t. each other and plot the probability distribution of errors in FigureÂ (5(b)). Observe that for the considered range of observations-noise, both certifiable solvers return similar solutions, while our proposal attains lower errors in rotation. This difference can be partially explained by the procedure that the SDP employs to extract the solution, that may have associated some rounding errors. While these differences are small, the computational time required by each solver does differ: the SDP requires 555 milliseconds and the proposed pipeline takes only 500500500 microseconds in average. That is, while the solution obtained by our proposal is similar in all occasions (if not better), reflecting in turn that the iterative solver does attain the global optimum repeatedly, the certifiable pipeline is at least ten times faster than the SDP.

From a implementation point of view, we should also remark that our certification algorithm does not require specific tools, as the convex relaxations do. The proposed solver allows to estimate the variable by any means and then, it certifies the given solution. The latter requires the resolution of a linear system in six variables and the computation of two eigenvalues (one of them can be computed in closed-form), operations that any mathematical library provide with.

VII-B Experiments on Synthetic data

We design four types of experiments, each of them target to show a different aspect of our proposal:

  • â€¢

    In this first set (SectionÂ (VII-B1)) we show the performance of the current implementation with the simplification of the essential matrix manifold introduced in SectionÂ (V-A). We also prove empirically that the proposed preconditioner in SectionÂ (V-A) does reduce the number of iterations of the RTR solver.

  • â€¢

    In this second set (SectionÂ (VII-B2)) we compare the proposed certifiable pipeline with state-of-the-art methodsÂ [11] in both performance and computation time.

  • â€¢

    In this third set (SectionÂ (VII-B3)) we compare the performance of Bundle-adjustment (minimization of reprojection error) when initialized with minimal solvers and our proposal.

  • â€¢

    In this fourth set (SectionÂ (VII-B4)) we introduce outliers and compare the performance of our robust pipeline (SectionÂ (VI)) against minimal solvers embedded into a RANSAC framework, which can be considered as the most common approach to robustification.

We employ the same procedure to generate the random data for all our synthetic experiments, which is the same procedure used in previous works Â [13], [27]. We summarize it here for completeness: We place the first camera frame at the origin (identity orientation and zero translation) and generate a set of random 3D points within a frustum with depth ranging from one to eight meters measured from the first camera frame and inside its Field of View (FoV). Then, we generate a random pose for the second camera whose translation magnitude is bounded above by â€–ğ’•â€–maxsubscriptnormğ’•max||\bm{t}||_{\text{max}}. We also enforce that all the 3D points lie within the second cameraâ€™s FoV. We create the correspondences as unit bearing vectors and add noise by assuming a spherical camera, computing the tangential plane at each bearing vector (point on the sphere) and introducing a random error sampled from the standard uniform distribution, considering a focal length of 800 pixels for both cameras.

Influence of Initialization: Here we show the influence of the initialization on the performance of the proposed pipeline. FigureÂ (7(a)) depicts the percentage of cases with certified optimal solution. On the other hand, the solutions obtained with the random and identity matrices tend to percentages below 40%percent4040\% and 30%percent3030\%, respectively. This last result reflects a considerable difference with respect toÂ [13], in which we obtain an increasing percentage of optimal solutions (up to 95%percent9595\%) with the number of correspondences for these initializations. The simplification of the essential matrix manifold in this work, while it does not seem to affect the refinements initialized with the 5-pt , 7-pt or 8-pt algorithms, it hinders the optimizations with poor initializations. In practice, however, one should never initialize the algorithm with these matrices; even a â€œbadâ€œ estimation (e.g. high noise and 8-pt ) is shown to attain the global optimum with high probability. In terms of computational time, we observe that for all the cases the complete certifiable pipeline takes less than 400â€‹Î¼â€‹sâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹s400ğœ‡ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ 400\mu secs to return a solution.

VII-B2 Comparison with state-of-the-art estimators without outliers

In these experiments, we compare the proposed certifiable pipeline with the state-of-the-art non-minimal methods. We denote by EIGÂ the estimator proposed in [11], by BAÂ the non-linear iterative minimization of the reprojection error and by BAREDÂ the same non-linear optimization, but restricted to ten random correspondences. We employ the implementation for these methods as it is provided by the computer vision library opengv Â [56]. Recall that none of these methods is able to certify optimality.

We generate random instances with the default parameters given above and for each combination, we generate 500 instances. In this case, the number of correspondences are N={8,10,12,20,40,60,80,100,120,150,170,200}ğ‘8101220406080100120150170200N=\{8,10,12,20,40,60,80,100,120,150,170,200\}. We initialize all the algorithms with the same point (ğ‘¹,ğ’•)ğ‘¹ğ’•(\bm{R},\bm{t}) obtained from the 8-pt .

FigureÂ (9(a)) shows the rotation error in logarithmic scale, measured as the geodesic distance between the estimated rotation and the ground truth. Note that EIGÂ and OURSÂ have similar error, of the order of BA. FigureÂ (9(b)) depicts the computation time required by the optimization stage in log-microseconds for the different methods.

While the error attained by OURS,Â EIGÂ and BAÂ are similar for problem instances with Nâ‰¥20ğ‘20N\geq 20, FigureÂ (9(b)) shows that OURSÂ required less time to achieve the same solution than the other two. Since BAREDÂ only employs 10 correspondences, it requires less CPU time although attains the largest error among all the methods.

VII-B3 Influence in Bundle-Adjustment

In this set of experiments we compare the performance, both in error and time, of the non-linear BA initialized with the previous minimal solvers and our proposal, since these minimal solvers are usually employed as initialization. We compare the 5-pt Â (denoted as BA-5PT), the 7-pt Â (BA-7PT) and the 8-pt Â (BA-8PT) with our proposal (BA-OURS). We generate random problem instances with the default parameters and vary the level of noise. We fix the number of correspondences in 999 and feed each method with their minimal number of points (our approach is executed with the 999 points). The multiple solutions are disambiguate with the remaining points. We create 500 random problem instances for each level of noise.

FigureÂ (10(a)) depicts the error in rotation (log-degrees) w.r.t. the ground truth for each solution returned by BA with the different initialization. While the 7-pt Â and 8-pt Â perform similarly, OURSÂ attains the lowest error despite the noise. In terms of time, FigureÂ (10(b)) shows the computation time required by BA (in log Î¼â€‹sâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹sğœ‡ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ \mu secs) for all the algorithms. Similarly, 7-pt and 8-pt require comparable times, while OURSÂ is faster. The computational times reported in this set of experiments did not include the initialization stage, only the time required by the BA to converge. We observe that in general our proposed pipeline increase the accuracy of BA and reduce the time to covergence.


VII-B4 Performance of the robust certifiable pipeline and comparison with state-of-the-art methods with outliers

This last set of experiments on synthetic data is aimed to show the resiliency of our robust proposed pipeline (AlgorithmÂ (2)) in SectionÂ (VI) against outliers: we apply the algorithm with the Tukeyâ€™s biweight (Tukey) and Geman-McClure (GM) loss functions. We also compare it with the non-iterative solvers, i.e. 5-pt ,Â 7-pt Â and 8-pt , embedded in a RANSAC framework.

We generate random problem instances with the default parameters. In order to help the methods, we employ 200200200 points and increase the FOVÂ up to 150150150Â degrees. We introduce outliers by substituting the correspondence associated with the second frame by a random (unitary) vector. We increase the percentage of outliers with a fixed step of 5%percent55~{}\% and for each of them, we generate 100100100 random problem instances.

FigureÂ (11(a)) shows the error in rotation (degrees) for each compared method. While the approaches based in RANSAC fail with 30%percent3030\% of outliers (the one with 5-pt Â performs better than 7-pt Â and 8-pt Â though), the proposed approach is able to return a solution with low error up to 50%percent5050\% of bad correspondences. Further, up to 70%percent7070\% of outliers (high ratio of outliers), the error attained by our proposal remains below 40â€‹degrees40degrees40~{}\text{degrees} (with a mean value of 11â€‹degrees11degrees11~{}\text{degrees}), while the RANSAC paradigms go up to 180â€‹degrees180degrees180~{}\text{degrees} (minimum mean value is 62â€‹degrees62degrees62~{}\text{degrees}).

FigureÂ (11(b)) shows the percentage of detected outliers (Y-axis) for each method as a function of the percentage of generated outliers (X-axis). These results provide an explanation on the errors depicted in (11(a)): when the number of detected inliers decrease (see e.g. our method with more than 55%percent5555\% outliers), the solution returned attain highest errors.

Computational cost: Last, we summarize here the computational cost of AlgorithmÂ (2) and compare it against the average values for the RANSAC paradigms. The proposed algorithm requires 60âˆ’80608060-80 outer iterations and 3âˆ’4343-4 inner iterations for any rate of outliers (except for 0%percent00\% of outliers, case in which it only runs one iteration) and the set of parameters employed. The relative pose estimation is the slowest step in the Algorithm, taking an average of 300â€‹Î¼â€‹sâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹s300ğœ‡ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ 300~{}\mu secs. In total, the robust pipeline requires 20âˆ’30â€‹mâ€‹sâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹s2030ğ‘šğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ 20-30~{}msecs to estimate a solution. On the other hand, RANSAC-based schemes take an average of 1âˆ’2â€‹mâ€‹sâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹s12ğ‘šğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ 1-2~{}msecs, being slower when the 5-pt is used as minimal solver and/or when the number of outliers is large.

VII-C Experiments on Real Data

To conclude this experimental validation, we evaluate our robust certifiable proposal (AlgorithmÂ (2)) on real data. To cover a wide regimen of real scenarios we select three available datasets, with both indoor and outdoor scenes, ground truth and intrinsic calibration parameters: ETH3DÂ [57], TUMÂ [58] and CVPR08Â [59]. The sequences employed here are listed in theÂ Online ResourceÂ (SectionÂ (D)). For all of them, we generate the correspondences by extracting and matching 100 SURF featuresÂ [60]. We compute the equivalent unitary bearing vectors by applying the pin-hole camera model with the provided intrinsic parameters for each frame. For each pair of images, we run the minimal solvers (5-pt , 7-pt and 8-pt ) embedded into a RANSAC scheme (RANSAC-5PT, RANSAC-7PT, RANSAC-8PT) and our proposed robust pipeline (OURS).

FigureÂ (12) depicts the error in rotation (in terms of geodesic distance) for all the tested methods. For our proposal, we also include the error for those solutions that were certified as optimal (OURS-CERT). We observe how our robust pipeline achieves better results in general than the most employed robust solvers. See also how the optimal solutions tend to attain the lower errors. However, an optimal solution does not guarantee that all the outliers are discarded: the certification is performed for a concrete problem instance and solution. Last, the percentage of certified optimal solutions for each dataset were: ETH3DÂ 98.5379%percent98.537998.5379\%, TUMÂ 82.6201%percent82.620182.6201\% and CVPR08Â 99.0741%percent99.074199.0741\%. We break down the percentage for each sequence and provide the error in rotation in the Online ResourceÂ (E).

VIII Conclusions and Future Work

In this work we extended our previous work inÂ [13] and proposed an efficient and robust certifiable relative pose estimation. We stated the RPp as as optimization problem that minimizes the squared, normalized epipolar error over the set of normalized essential matrices. We provided a family of closed-form dual candidates derived from the six different relaxations of the set of essential matrices. These optimality certifiers were incorporated as final stage of an efficient, certifiable essential matrix estimation pipeline that first estimates a solution to the RPp by iteratively refining on the product space of 3D rotations and 2-sphere an initial guess for this problem. We derived the Euclidean quadratic model of the RPp required by the iterative solver. To speed up the convergence of the solver, we proposed a suitable preconditioner that also increased the number of certified solutions. Our proposal was proved through extensive experiments on synthetic data to be more accurate than the state-of-the-art closed-form methods, and faster than the iterative solvers. We showed that the gold standard approach for the RPp, the 2-view Bundle-adjustment, converged faster and attained a lower error when initialized with the output of our algorithm in comparison with other suitable initializations.

We integrated our certifiable approach into the robust paradigm formed by the combination of Graduated Non-convexity and the Black-Rangarajan duality between robust and line process. Our robust pipeline was proved to be less sensible to high rates of outliers (up to 50%percent5050\%) in comparison with the common RANSAC approaches with the closed-form solvers. Last, our evaluation on real data confirmed the observations derived from the previous experiments, and more than 80%percent8080\% of optimal solutions were certified for the three datasets considered. We made the code publicly available as an additional contribution, and also provided a generic library that implemented the robust paradigm here defined that was not restricted to the RPp.

As future work, we consider the extension of our certifiable stage to consider other minimal characterizations of the set of essential matrices. Further enhancements on the verification algorithm are being considered for implementation.

  5. 5.

    Apply the associative property of the kronecker product, i.e. ğ’‚âŠ—(ğ’ƒ+â€¦â€‹ğ‘ª)=ğ’‚âŠ—ğ’ƒ+â€¦+ğ’‚âŠ—ğ‘ªtensor-productğ’‚ğ’ƒâ€¦ğ‘ªtensor-productğ’‚ğ’ƒâ€¦tensor-productğ’‚ğ‘ª\bm{a}\otimes(\bm{b}+...\bm{C})=\bm{a}\otimes\bm{b}+...+\bm{a}\otimes\bm{C}.

  6. 6.

    â€Moveâ€ the constant, scalar terms tj,tksubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜t_{j},t_{k} outside the sums. Finally, swap the order of the sums.

Appendix C Terms of the quadratic model for the cost function in terms of the rotation and translation

In this Section we derive the Euclidean gradient and Hessian of the cost function considered in this work w.r.t. the points on the manifold SOâ€‹(3)Ã—ğ’®2SO3superscriptğ’®2\text{SO}(3)\times\mathcal{S}^{2}.

Since the considered manifold is a direct product, its tangent bundle TMÂ [42] is expressed as: Â TM=Tğ‘¹Ã—Tğ’•Â TMsubscriptTğ‘¹subscriptTğ’•\text{ {TM}}=\text{T}_{\bm{R}}\times\text{T}_{\bm{t}}, where Tğ‘¹subscriptTğ‘¹\text{T}_{\bm{R}} and Tğ’•subscriptTğ’•\text{T}_{\bm{t}} are the tangent bundles of SOâ€‹(3)SO3\text{SO}(3) and ğ’®2superscriptğ’®2\mathcal{S}^{2}, respectivelyÂ [16]. This implies that we can write any vector field YË™Ë™ğ‘Œ\dot{Y} as the composition of its components in the two subspaces Tğ‘¹,Tğ’•subscriptTğ‘¹subscriptTğ’•\text{T}_{\bm{R}},\text{T}_{\bm{t}} i.e., YË™=(YË™SOâ€‹(3),YË™ğ’®2)âˆˆTğ‘¹Ã—Tğ’•Ë™ğ‘ŒsubscriptË™ğ‘ŒSO3subscriptË™ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ’®2subscriptTğ‘¹subscriptTğ’•\dot{Y}=(\dot{Y}_{\text{SO}(3)},\dot{Y}_{\mathcal{S}^{2}})\in\text{T}_{\bm{R}}\times\text{T}_{\bm{t}}, which simplifies the derivation of them.
